<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```typescript
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```

<<<explanation>>>: The problem with the regex you provided is that it only matches the first occurrence of the state abbreviation. To match all occurrences, you need to use a non-greedy match with the `*` character. Also, you need to make sure that the regex pattern is case-insensitive and can match both uppercase and lowercase letters.

Here's an updated regex pattern that should work for your case:
```java
String re1 = "(\\d+)"; // Integer Number 1
String re2 = "(?i)\\b[a-z]+\\b"; // Word 1 (case-insensitive)
String re3 = "(?i)\\b[a-z]+\\b"; // Word 2 (case-insensitive)
String re4 = "(?i)\\b[a-z]+\\b"; // Word 3 (case-insensitive)
String re5 = "(?i)\\b[a-z]+\\b"; // Word 4 (case-insensitive)
String re6 = "(?i)\\b[a-z]+\\b"; // Word 5 (case-insensitive)
String re7 = "(?i)\\b[a-z]+\\b"; // Word 6 (case-insensitive)
```
Note that I added the `(?i)` flag to the regex pattern to make it case-insensitive. Also, I changed the word boundaries to `\b` to make sure that the pattern matches at the beginning and end of the word.

With these changes, the regex pattern should match all occurrences of the state abbreviation, regardless of the number of words in the city name.
